contentList.content: A double walled, reinforced storage container for various unguents and oils used to coat weapons and arrowheads.
Safely store your weapon and arrowhead poisons and other substances.
Sturdy enough to endure rocky voyages or decades stacked ten-deep in a dusty warehouse.
A chest suitable for lashing to carts and wagons.
A place to store jewelry and other small valuables.

The silvery gleam and delicate tracery of this decorative locking jewelry box belies its durability. Intended for use while traveling, it is lined in luxurious crushed velvet to give your sparkling baubles a safe place to rest.
Fashioned at the hands of someone deeply skilled... or, at the very least, someone who was having a good day at the loom and tailor shop.
This lovely ensemble is evocative of the apron of a master chocolatier - and just as scrumptious.
Crisply white with snatches of blue, this garment would not be out of place at a winter festival gala celebrating the wearer's sense of style.
Perfect for ambling around a campsite, enjoying the starlight and good conversation.
A once-fine shirt that's seen years of cuts, tears, and careful repairs. Clearly someone cares about looking good.
Somehow Gale has managed to make his clothes smell like a library. To inhale their aroma is to feel a sudden urge to speak more quietly. Or pay a fine.
Feeling the fabric, the strangest feeling occurs: your thumbs brush sun-dappled leaves, skim the water of a creek, tangle in the fur of some panting animal, heat and breath.
Though humble in appearance, these clothes bear little hints at Jaheira's fashionability. Minimalism offset by the subtle hues shining brighter at night and softening in sunbeams.
Torn and hell-scented, these trousers have seen a good deal of action - though not perhaps the sort Karlach might prefer.
As exciting as a trade deposition and as functional as a brick.
To the metaphorical eye, an absolute fantasia of an outfit, declaiming Minsc as a style icon without equal. To the literal eye, this is a belt-buckle shirt/pants combo.
While there is little of the spidery Goddess Lolth's influence in this outfit, there is something of spiney inflexible culture of the drow in it.
A little bar of standard-issue cloister soap is tucked into this outfit. It smells like lime and religious fervour.
In his good-humoured performativity, Wyll could not resist a puff of perfume on these clothes. Possibly eau du Frontiers.
Stylish without being altogether noteworthy, though the embroidery is actually very fine in certain lights.
Accentuating all features, turning stockiness into slenderness, turning a beer-belly into... well, an ale gut, but even so! A win overall!
A most adventuresome and spring-heeled variety of ensemble, perfect for journey-makers and risk-takers.

Adorned with the tripartite symbol of the Absolute, this ensemble of black and green presents the wearer as either a mocker or a devotee of the cult. Or someone who likes the cut and colour. Or someone who is cold.
Golden vambraces and arm rings surmount this divine set.
With its harsh, almost arachnid cut and shape, this outfit evokes the spiderlike denizens of the Underdark.
A minimalist leather binding get-up that clings to the skin and creaks just the slightest bit when you move.
A minimalist leather binding get-up that clings to the skin and creaks just the slightest bit when you move.
A minimalist leather binding get-up that clings to the skin and creaks just the slightest bit when you move.
A minimalist leather binding get-up that clings to the skin and creaks just the slightest bit when you move.
Some craftsperson of the highest calibre envisioned and created this, and anyone who wears it shall be the envy of not only their friends, but their enemies too.
Black as volcanic glass and just as valuable, this ensemble would turn the eye of an entire court.
When held out in the sun, the sleeves almost glitter, so richly woven is the fabric of this outfit.
Each stitch not embellished with filigree and gold weave is gorgeous as the polished scales of a green dragon fully grown.
Though the name is an exaggeration (the fabled city's heat would burn the fabric black stitch by stitch), the sheer magnificence of this ensemble's appeal is not.
Grey with accumulated road dust, these clothes are nothing special.
Patchwork and threadbare, these clothes practically dangle off their wearer.
Keenly administered to by the sort of fingers that were born stitching, crocheting, and generally making nice clothes.
This outfit makes the wearer feel like a ray of sunlight swanning around camp.
This outfit makes the wearer feel like a brilliant green turaco bird.
This outfit makes the wearer feel like a bouquet of puya flowers, except with legs, and great style.
Capably crafted, giving the impression of affirming wealth,
Tailored with immaculate skill, this outfit makes you feel like a Luskan noble walking their manor instead of a wilderland camp.
Nimble fingers designed and created this outfit.
Tailored with immaculate skill, this outfit makes you feel like someone who has elevated beige. Beige is an atrocious colour, yet here it is, very impressive and pleasing on the eye.
Modelled on the chandeliers in the Waterdhavian Sea Ward - aesthetically pleasing and most grand.
This outfit makes you feel like a piece of the summer sky transmuted into silk.
This outfit makes you feel like a red dragon's fiery breath, only the deadliness lies in sheer aesthetic beauty.
Backless so that people can pat you on the back and proclaim, 'I say, lovely outfit.'
There is something of the blue-blooded rebel in this outfit, of the bandit princess or prince stealing plunder and hearts.
There is something of the green-grinning rebel in this outfit, of the bandit princess or prince stealing plunder and hearts.
There is something of the purple-peacock rebel in this outfit, of the bandit princess or prince stealing plunder and hearts.
There is something of the pale-white-toothed rebel in this outfit, of the bandit princess or prince stealing plunder and hearts.
Presumably named for a courageous person. Regardless, a marvellously decadent outfit.
Robust, sleek, and flattering, this ensemble presents a very fetching figure for the wearer.
Robust, sleek, and flattering, this ensemble presents a very fetching figure for the wearer.
Diamonds are like the colour black - they simply go with everything.
Robust, sleek, and flattering, this ensemble presents a very fetching figure for the wearer.
Something slightly perilous and fun imbues this design of garments.
Raffish (meaning sly and disreputable in an alluring way) comes from Raffish Buck Daederum, whose fashion this ensemble mimicks closely.
Raffish (meaning sly and disreputable in an alluring way) comes from Raffish Buck Daederum, whose fashion this ensemble mimicks closely.
Raffish (meaning sly and disreputable in an alluring way) comes from Raffish Buck Daederum, whose fashion this ensemble mimicks closely.
Raffish (meaning sly and disreputable in an alluring way) comes from Raffish Buck Daederum, whose fashion this ensemble mimicks closely.
Austere and no-nonsense, this outfit betokens largesse and poise.

One of master Figaro's collection pieces, this outfit maintains the poise and grace of the wearer. Honestly, it elevates it considerably. Bad poise becomes competent poise. Competent becomes strong. Strong becomes spiffing.

One of master Figaro's collection pieces, this outfit maintains the poise and grace of the wearer. Honestly, it elevates it considerably. Bad poise becomes competent poise. Competent becomes strong. Strong becomes spiffing.

One of master Figaro's collection pieces, this outfit maintains the poise and grace of the wearer. Honestly, it elevates it considerably. Bad poise becomes competent poise. Competent becomes strong. Strong becomes spiffing.

One of master Figaro's collection pieces, this outfit maintains the poise and grace of the wearer. Honestly, it elevates it considerably. Bad poise becomes competent poise. Competent becomes strong. Strong becomes spiffing.
At camp, under the deep blue sky fading to indigo at the horizon, this shirt fits right in.
Purple as tasty plums shared by a camp tent.
Soft and green and ideal for a good sleep under the stars.
Dark and inexpensive, yet with a very charming cosiness once worn.
These shoes make light, almost imperceptible clicking noises as they walk on stone, the wood nice and sculpted.
The tanners had an excellent time producing this leather - they actually got to use real animal flesh. Usually they work with much grosser stuff.
Patterned with twists of gold, lilac and sapphire, these delicate shoes are very reasonable for dancing, romancing, perhaps even prancing.
The height of modern Sword Coastian fashion, provided you like being targetted by muggers and thugs and other interesting friendly people.
A mesh of webbed material protects the toes from errant spiders.
Slashes of leather gird the feet. A bright silvery button gleams.
Slashes of leather gird the feet. A bright silvery button gleams - this pair have seen better days.
A mesh of webbed material protects the toes from errant spiders - these seem brand new, and never worn.
Strapped and lined in an either piscine or arboreal motif, these sandals are perfect for a warm morning stroll.
Supported round the heel, these sandals provide good comfort for the unhurried peruser of brooks, streams, and stony woods.
Patterned as many knightly shields are in the modern era.
Cobblers have worked a diamond pattern into the sandals.
Worn by warriors upon the bloodiest sands.
The fragrance of warm-sanded shores and salt-thick waves permeates these sandals.
This lightweight, cushioned footwear was designed for silent footfall in sacred places.
Purified through sudden heating, these extracts have become vaporous, and are often linked to the element of air.
The process of refining salts gives them a granular texture, causing them to be linked to the element of earth.
Certain ingredients can be purified until only their essence remains. Due to their esoteric nature, these extracts are often linked to the Feywild.
All impurities have been burned off these extracts, and so they are logically linked to the element of fire.

Vitriols differ from other extracts in that refining them seems to make them accumulate all that is vile. Because of this, many have linked them to the Shadowfell. Still, their use cannot be understated.
Since water is indispensable in creating suspensions, they are commonly linked to that element.
Combine this dye with an equipment item to alter the colours of fabric, leather and even metal.
Light reflects off the many facets of this rough-cut gem, imported all the way from the jungles of Chult.
Smells a bit rusty, but looks stylish nonetheless.
These boots are stamped with the marks of a cancelled commission. Despite their discarded fate, they still hum with complex infernal arcana.
These gauntlets spark with unfinished, yet still potent devillish magic - indicative of a cancelled blacksmith's commission.

Nothing stings the master blacksmith more than a cancelled commission - not even molten iron. This mail is engraved with the mark of a devillish forgemaster, as well as several curses stamped out in Infernal, and hums with diabolic magic.
Many a githyanki hunter has worn this amulet before you. The strange stones set in swirling silver reverberate with echoes of their magic.

Touching this amulet's centrepiece, you are imbued with a vision of woven strands, and the strands coming apart and holding true and firm over your friends, like shields banded in a haze of golden light.

Imbued with a little luck after the item was pressed to the pursed lips of a saint of the goddess Tymora. Inscribed roughly and inexpertly on the underside: 'Lady Luck, don't you piss in my porridge oats!'
This ring is missing its gem - or perhaps it's just very invisible.
A glob of tree sap studded with dead ants occupies the space where this ring's stone once sat.
The exterior of this ring is roughly carved with nonsensical runes.
A small pebble swings from a length of fishing line tied to this copper ring.
The runes encircling this ring appear to have been scratched into the metal with a rock.
The product of a fletcher's fine work, meant to be fired from a bow.
An old, leather collar for a large dog. The name 'Myrna' is engraved on the tag, surrounded by a plethora of indecipherable runes.
This amulet, engraved with a small waterfall, imparts a feeling of calm serenity when worn.
A silver amulet depicting the symbol of Bhaal.
Tiny specks of blood cover this amulet. They have pooled into the engravings on the back, spelling out the name 'Wulbren' in a grisly brown hue.
Slightly tarnished, and opened with a mere flick of the thumb.
An aged, blue-stained scrap of paper within this locket reads: 'To Mayrina - Will you go to the summer fair with me? From Connor. PS. These bluebells are from Ma Grundy's patch, please don't tell!'

Though they only worked together for a short time, it is hard to overstate the influence Lenore the cleric of Mystra had on Yrre the Sparkstruck, who often likened harnessing lightning to manipulating the Weave.
Donning this necklace causes the room to sway and tip - or maybe it was already swaying? Whatever, time for another pint.
The tourmaline in this necklace is almost uncomfortably hot, warmed by a heat all its own.
The ruby's red reflections look like eerie flames dancing across your skin.
Each sapphire feels like a tiny shard of sharpened ice.

The gem in this collar's centre is placed as a common courtesy: it allows the tressym's summoner to be identified and complained to in the case of bereaved pet owners or pigeon-masters. This one glows with a Waterdhavian name: Gale Dekarios.
Eldritch sigils seem to coarse through the metalwork on this amulet.
Though thin and delicate-looking, the amulet's pendant sits heavy against your chest.
Originally the kidney stone of an archfey, this object has been, ahem, passed down through the centuries.
Nobility can be found in suffering the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune. So can dying. Best to be on guard.
Each of this amulet's jewels shines like a viper's eyes.
The gemstone centrepiece of the amulet was long ago mottled and dyed by the tears of a martyr.
Fingering this amulet sends a spike of pleasure sliding through the brain - pleasure that could be turned to pain in an enemy's addled mind.
Flowing through your chest, threads of whiskey-like warmth - they spread and spread, and who could lay you low, you champion in hopeful hours?
The bauble is emblazoned with fiendish words that, when translated, mean, 'May your throat be educated in new screams.'
When on the wrong side of a few sherries, the powerful wizards Bigby and Tenser would sometimes see how many spells they could fit into amulets like this one before they burst.
The back bears an inscription under a delicate crescent moon. 'You're a novice no more, Robin. Only right you should carry a little of our Lady's light with you.'
Named after the god of martyrs, this amulet seems to shine in the presence of the wearer's blood.
'Let your lips turn black as night/On this eve of frightful wights/Let your throat be filled with screams/Nearby looms the Raven Queen!' - A song of dark festivity
Worn by Lumi, a cleric beholden to twilight, who sheltered her fellow adventurers as a bantam shelters her chicks.
Chiselled into the back of the amulet with great care: 'sorcery > wizardry'.
Otto, a member of the powerful arcane organisation the Circle of Eight, had a penchant for amulets. So much so that they announced his arrival before he ever needed to.
There are no molluscs of power, alas.
Sometimes the best thing you can do for your friends is to stop bleeding and give them a chance to sort everything out.
This beetle-shaped medallion thrums with a power redolent of older civilisations in Toril - how old is this relic, all grouted with dust as it is?
Some scholars have speculated that spells have a mind of their own, suggesting that the spells get bored between being cast and restored.

One of the relics of Deep Duerra's rebellious children. Drugging the Keykeeper of Duerra's vaults, the children crept in under cover of night and plundered their mother's treasure - searching desperately for anything that would aid in their flight.
Spectators are hideous aberrations that float above the ground, fiercely staring around and shooting beams at anything they don't appreciate.
Quivers creep up your enemy's back - the slow, long-fingered hand of your magic.
A surgeon is only as reliable as her tools. And, indeed, as depraved.
The air surrounding this lavishly decorated amulet is thick - like pushing your fingers through sap or syrup.
The green jewel set into this necklace's pendant is carved to resemble a cat's slivered pupil.
Each jewel gleams with the energy of the natural elements.
The dead hold no secrets from Jergal's Scriveners of Doom.

This necklace allows the wearer to cast Misty Step.

Made of blue gems unique to a privately-owned mine in Menzoberranzan, this necklace was likely a token of esteem - or perhaps a desperate attempt to win its recipient's mercy.
Stained by blood, and gifted to only the most faithful of True Souls to help preserve their lives.
The gems and pearls of this necklace have a brilliant shine to them, as if reflecting unseen moonlight.
Once part of the Girdle of Blades, this buckle was torn off and fashioned into an amulet that can be worn by creatures of all sizes.
Sun-graced warmth radiates from both the pendant and its chain. Somehow, even a brief glance of it brings a smile to your face.
A plump mass torn from Sovereign Glut's own flesh. A marker of the colony's esteem - or perhaps its property.
A fleshy amulet shaped by Sovereign Spaw's own hand. Wherever the bearer goes, so does the myconid circle.
Beneath the layers of dust covering this necklace, its inlaid gems still give off a blue sparkle - the colour of Mystra's clergy.
Grime covers this necklace, but you can vaguely discern delicate engravings of a moon and harp.
A menacing cackle emanates from this twisted charm. It whispers to bite, to maim, to kill...
A pale green eye, pierced by the twisting branches of a dead tree - the result of a foolhardy woman begging Auntie for a favour.
While this doesn't prevent wilful rest, it does protect you from being put to sleep from such sources as hypnotism, copious alcohol usage, or, indeed, magic.
Grants its wearer the ability to cast <LSTag Type="Spell" Tooltip="Target_DancingLights">Dancing Lights</LSTag>.
Worked carefully into the locket's metal back are the words, 'Never dark again.'
A gift from Khalid for Jaheira.
Allows you to cast Charm Person once per short rest
The inlaid jewels are so rich in colour, so deep in hue, you could lose yourself in them.
Every gem hanging from this necklace is warm to the touch, as if waiting to ignite.
Grimy, discoloured, and revoltingly ugly. Auntie Ethel must have made it herself. Surprisingly, you feel no disgust. Instead it fills you with a longing, as if it's calling out for its like.
Love is the sweetest bird that might migrate to the charming country of your heart.
Love is the last cruel leaf to fall in an autumn wide with sorrow.
Adjusting this unassuming ring on your finger, you hear a faint sizzle, as of pressure being released.
What better way to disguise one's transgressions than a quickly positioned phantasm after the deed is done?

A year into their union, Lenore, cleric of Mystra, gifted the gnome inventor Yrre an invention of her own devising - a ring that held a spell of sparks. Eventually, the touch of Lenore's hand faded to a glinting memory, but the ring's tingling grip remained resolute.

When the inventor Yrre met the cleric Lenore, sparks flew. Apart, they were in a rut, but together, they inspired each other to push the boundaries of innovation and invention. This ring is just one of their many scientific triumphs.
Though the ring is highly polished, darkened slivers of blood still cling to small scrapes and corners.
The mysterious gem set in this ring seems to change hues whenever you aren't looking.
A burning heat radiates from this ring, warming the wearer from head to toe.
Every one of the three gems in this ring is searing hot - enough to burn yourself with the slightest brush of your fingers.
A series of names have been scratched out, one after the other, on the inside of the ring. The last word, untouched, is not a name. It simply reads: Mine.
Fashioned by the wizard Bigby in honour of his faithful hound Bigboy, who could use teleportation to fetch, snare errant cats, and generally harass postmen.
A paralysing eyestalk harvested from a beholder was boiled in a broth, and poured down the throat of a dwarven ringsmith. Not one fortnight thence, he crafted this ring.
Created by a conglomerate of druids one moonlit night when all the stirring violins of insect, elms, and whispering winds consorted, and when wild beasts in need of taming prowled unseen.
The sharp silver corners of this ring almost cut into the stone set in its centre - a gem of which you've never seen the like before.
In his speculative writing on arcane displacement, the wizard Tenser notes the possibility for keenly focused minds to maintain spells, and even unlock hidden potential while doing so.
Glibness is not only in the tongue, but in the body. Gesture is powerful. Think of how many words of comfort can be stored and saved, when a hug will do just as sweetly.
Organisations like the Harpers do not relegate their activities to head-to-head combat - many a moonlit chase with an evildoer has been resolved with a loose roof tile and a decent throwing arm.
Dark smoke swirls in the ring's onyx, protecting something within.
Whispers in the Deep Speech of the Underdark insinuate themselves into the mind of whoever so much as brushes against the burnished metal of this ring.
Tiny barbs prick the wearer when they're injured, as if urging flight from danger.
Gazing through this ring, you find that there is no other side, only a small sucking blackness that defies explanation.
This otherwise unassuming ring ties a spellcaster indelibly to the sporadic arcana of the Faerie realm.

Slipping one's finger through this ring fills the senses with the waft of tombs, the urine-yellow smell of old bandages, images of dead spiders curled into husks, and the sensation of hot, slobbering breath at the nape of one's neck.
When light catches this ring at the right angle, it pulses with a dizzying, intoxicating glow befitting the jewellery of the Prince of the Comet.
For some, darkness is wielded like a black opal stud embedded in a signet ring - fashioned to a sharp and unforgiving point.
Decorated with a hummingbird wrought of jade and sapphire, this ring evokes the sheer wonderful quickness of that animal.
The heart of the gem seems to flow like liquid - yet it contains neither quicksilver nor mercury.
The ring is scuffed and twisted out of shape, as if worn by big stony fingers. The owner of those fingers has carved 'Karthol' into the warped metal in a fit of affection or possessiveness.
This ring is, in effect, a tiny field medic that won't charge you 70 gold pieces for a fifteen-minute consultation.
Elegant motifs of warding - shields, targes, bucklers, and buffers - are faintly impressed into the metal round of the ring.
Strange, green fumes seep from the ring's emerald.
The patterns in the ring's swirling metal make your head spin whenever you look at them for too long.
A grudging gleam emits from this ring - more an indictment of light than an endorsement.
Provocative light blooms from the engraved contours of this ring.
Life is just a series of risks taken while blindfolded.

One of the relics of Deep Duerra's rebellious children. Paranoid by nature, Duerra had erected a vast array of biting, blasting, blinding traps and safeguards to keep her enemies from gaining her sanctum.

Of course, this also meant her children were sealed in with her by those same deadly measures.

One of the relics of Deep Duerra's rebellious children. Long ago in a foreboding realm called Hammergrim, Deep Duerra, daughter of the dour god Laduguer, sired a great many heirs to her twisted corundum throne.
'I'm a talented shapeshifter, too. I can shapeshift a thin body into a fat body. All I need is a steady supply of mince pies and mulled wine.' - Overheard in a tavern in Daggerford
A common ring, simple and unadorned. Though there is a certain heft to it...
When you slip this ring on your hand and flex your fingers, a boom of discontented thunder grumbles in the air around you.
'Fib now, and forever hold your teeth.' - Folk saying
Equip this ring to increase your <LSTag Tooltip="Perception">Perception Skill</LSTag> by [1].
Mud cakes the tiny letters of an inscription - 'A Cursed Sight Doth Dwell Beneath'.
Though caked with mud and grime, the ring smells faintly of lavender. Remarkable, considering where it's been.
This gemstone used to be in a ring.
A radiant and remarkably preserved ring, forged from arandur metal.
This ring coaxes anyone branded by the Absolute. Their fingers veritably itch to slip it on.
The ring's emerald glows a deep, deadly green.
Darkness seems to blossom from this ring, heightened by the menacing glare of the Absolute's symbol, though for the Branded this symbol holds the promise of power.
This ring is forged from a smooth, alien metal, capped with eyes of emerald that watch the world unblinking.
Though carefully stowed away in a bedside chest, this ring is covered in dust and cobwebs.
Used by the previous owner to access both the Underdark's darkest corners and her own basement, this ring seems to reflect light where there should be none.
Formless, unsettling dread fills any normal folk that don this ring - the transpositional magic thrumming within wishes to be used by only one specific scion of murder.
This ring carries the symbol of the Szarr family and has an inscription in some crusty old language.
A soft, soothing voice floats from this ring, reciting a prayer over and over.
A subtle accessory prized by purveyors of the covert arts.
Even in the brightest light, this ring never gleams, as if perpetually wrapped in shadow, hungry for the dark.

The scholar of love, Joel Firris Baldidims, writes that the next time he reads about a woman compared to a flower (or any feature of geography for that matter) he's going to start knocking on poets' doors with a sledgehammer.

The most pragmatic and courageous lover ever known was, of course, Sorcha MacTire, for whom the popular hairstyle is named, and for whom many an extremely soppy poem has been written (most of them comparing her to geography).
The ring's arcane jewel parts all but the darkest of shadows.
A hymn to Eilistraee is inscribed along the inside of this ring, which is surprisingly heavy when worn.
The ring from the djinni who worked in the circus. Its magic certainly explains how the djinni was able to cheat at the wheel.
A ring that has been robbed of its gemstone.
Considered sacred by some gnomes and halflings, the gem set in this ring sparkles brilliantly.
When the light hits it just so, the centre jewel shimmers with every colour of the rainbow.
The ring's simplicity is a deceit. Its gold core is woven with iron-hard feathers from the wings of great black corvid birds, envoys of the Raven Queen.
The smooth, six-pointed star on this ring is beset with small Underdark gemstones, as befits a talisman of the god of mining and patron of deep gnomes.
A shiny, deceptively simple band, designed to look like those worn by battlefield scouts and city pickpockets alike.
